Award.AwardTitle: Synthetic Integration of Inorganic-Organic Functionality in Hybrid Semiconductors Based on Chalcogenide Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award in the Inorganic, Bioinorganic and Organometallic Chemistry program supports research by Professor Pingyun Feng at the University of California at Riverside to develop solid-state materials based on chalcogenide tetrahedral clusters and various functional organic species. The proposed research seeks to explore structural and functional diversity of organic molecules to control the crystallization process and structures of chalcogenide clusters and frameworks and to modify and enhance optical and electrooptical properties of resulting chalcogenide clusters and composite materials (integrating both clusters and functional organic components). Three unique types of composite materials will be targeted in which chalcogenide clusters are integrated (1) with optically active metal-complex or organic dye molecules into the dye-sensitized system, (2) with organic electron acceptors into the charge-transfer system or stable radicals, and (3) with ligands with extended systems into covalently organized multi-dimensional systems. With new composite materials developed, this project will investigate their electronic, optical, and photoelectrochemical properties for potential use in applications such as solar energy conversion into fuels or electricity.

New materials developed in this project could lead to new applications in solar energy conversion, chemical sensors, and biosensors. UC Riverside has a high African-American and Hispanic enrollment and strongly encourages undergraduate research. The proposed work will provide training for students in synthesis, structural characterization, and property measurements and prepare them for careers in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to integrate synthetic and structural principles developed from cluster chemistry and crystalline nanoporous solids to create a new class of cluster-based inorganic-organic hybrid semiconducting porous materials with potential applications in various energy- and environment-related areas. In addition, the synthesis of size-tunable semiconducting nanoclusters with optically and photochemically active metal complexes and organic systems makes it possible to produce materials with unprecedented structural, optical, and electronic properties due to synergistic effects resulting from uniform molecular-level integration of both components. With the support of this NSF, a number of new materials with interesting properties have been developed. One example is our development of an entirely new series of chalcogenide clusters and a new structural mechanism for the formation of large semiconducting tetrahedral clusters. These materials are based on sodium chloride-type core and cubic zinc blende-like shell. Another example is the synthesis and characterization of a  precisely hollowed-out cubic zinc blende-type superlattice constructed from hierarchically ordered supertetrahedra.. Such “hollowed-out" bulk material provides an ideal platform for exploring how the material’s property may change upon periodically removing inside atoms from a bulk single crystal. In addition to the above polymeric framework materials, we have also synthesized the large exact fragment of the cubic zinc blende-type lattice called isolated supertetrahedral cluster. The work revealed some unusual synthetic and structural chemistry, including (i) an unexpected phase transition from (usually highly stable) 3D framework into discrete clusters; prior to this work, it was generally perceived that 3D frameworks were preferred under such synthetic conditions and crystals of isolated clusters were difficult to form, especially at the expense of 3D frameworks; and (ii) an unusual way for the termination of cluster surface so that the properties of the materials can be further tuned by using different organic functionalities. In addition to tunable optical properties, some of these semiconducting materials are porous and show high adsorption for various gases such as CO2. This may have potential applications in the sensing of these gases and may also provide opportunities to convert these harmful chemicals to useful chemicals with the help of solar energy. The work is still in progress.

The project combined diversity in materials types and various measurement techniques and aimed to address one of the most pressing problems of our times: utilization of renewal energy and remediation of environments. It therefore provided excellent training opportunities for students in synthesis, structural characterization, and property measurements and prepared them for a challenging, but rewarding career in science.
